document.text: The office of the Custodian, Ap pomattox Court House National Historical Monument, Appomattox, today announced that title to the North Caiiolina i Monument Tract and Monument on the Appomattox Battlefield has been accepted uy the Secretary of the Interiors Of fice, on behalf of the United States. Donated by the State o f Naîtlr Carolina,the fifty-foot square tract and the granite monument will be included in the area admin istered by the Appomattox Court House National Historical . Monu ment under the jurisdiction of the National Park Service and the Uni ted States Department of the In terior. The North Carolina Monument was erected by the State of North Carolina in 1905 to locate the pos ition of North Carolina troops fir ing the last volley on the morning of April 9, 1865, in the last battle fought by Lees Army of Northern Virginia. A few hours after this action, Lee and Grant met at the McLean House half a mile distant from the scene of the last engage ment and signed the agreement for the. surrender of Lees Confederate forces. The position of North Carolina troops firing the last volley was located and identified by survivors of Coxs North Carolina Brigade on a visit to the battlefield in October, 1904. The story of the visit of these survivors and their location of pos itions held by North Carolina troops is told in a pamphlett pub lished by the North Carolina Liter ary and Historical Society in 1904. The map of the Appomattox Battle field which appears in this pamph lett is one of the few accurate source maps for the last engage ment of the Army of Northern Vir ginia. National Park Service officials stated, in reporting donation of this trac, that as soon as conditions permit thé road leading to the North Carolina Monument would be widened and improved and park ing facilities at the monument would be provided.

Most important restoration at the A.ppomattox Court House National Historical Monument will be the re- onstruction of the McLean House. M. E. Dunap purchased the house n 1891 for removal to the Chicago Worlds Fair as a museum exhibit. He later chose Washington, D. C., as the site for the re-erection, but ctually never moved the house at all, though the demolition was com pleted in 1893. C. W Hancock, the ocal contractor hired tc tear the building down, was also to have put it bsck together. He made fairly detailed specifications and employed P. C. Hubard of Lynchburg to draw plans. These plans and specifications purchased from Mr. Hubard and Mr. Hancocks heirs, will form the basis for the reconstruction, along with many wartime and other photo graphs, old drawings, and writings found by the historical staff of the Monument. Mr. Hubard is still a resident of Lynchburg. Archeological investigation at the site of the McLean House has been underway since early spring. The purpose of this investigation is two-j fold to check the Hancock-Hubard I drawings and specifications and to find new facts. The overall dimen sions of the house, as worked out by the archeologist, check almost to the inch with the Hancock-Hu bard data. New finds were to be ex pected because Hancock made the plans for his own infomation and had the actual material to use in the rebuilding and thus naturally eft out certain data. One of the finds was the stone and brick hearth on the ground flood. Also uncovered were remnants of the old wood stringers that supported the ground floor boards, as well as a drainage pit designed to keep the basement dry at all times. The Appomattox Court House National Historical Monument, a unit of the National Park Service, commemorates the ending of the Wrr Between the States and the re union of America. Company 1351, Camp NP28, Colored Veterans of the First World War, came to the area, July 22, 1941. National Park Service plans call for the reconstruction of the Mc Lean House, where the famous meet ing of Lee and Grant occurred Ap ril 9, 1865, reconstruction of the old court house builidng, and res toration of existing historis houses.  he old court house burned in 1892. M. E. Dunlap, of Niagga Falls, Y, had the McLean House torn down in 1893 for re-ereetton as a museum in Washington the museum proposal was not carried out, how ever, and the dismantled surrender house mouldered on the ground. After the rebuilding of the court house at a new site, now the town of Appomattox, the old village de clined. One of the first jobs under- aken by the men of Camp NP28 was the removal of honeysuckle and the dense corpses of locust trees that had grown around the de serted village.  Next they began the removal of non-histpric struc tures and the preliminary recondi tioning of the old houses to be res tored. During the coming months more clearing .will be done to ap proximate the 18,5 appearance of he village and further work on the restoration of the historic houses will be undertaken.. In the near future a by-pass road, to be a part of Virginia Highway 24, will be built around the old village in order that the village site can be completely restored to its historic appearance. Rock for this by-pass road has been gathered and crush ed by the CCC men and more is to be obtained soon and1 a quarry to be opened on park property. document.text: In a recent visit to the Old Sur render Grounds, Mrs. Bessie Fergu son and Mrs. Lennie Gills told the National Park Service staff about many of the buildings in the historic vi lage, particularly the homes and business places of their father, Will iam Rosser, and their uncle, John Rosser. Mrs. Fergusons former home is now the office of the Appomattox Court House National Historical Monument. They expressed the belief that Mrs. Mary Ellen Hickok, of San Diego, California, might remember something of the old tavern. Her grandfather, Wilson Hix, was the owner at the time of the surrender. A letter was dispatched to Mrs. Hickok, who answered not only with written information, but also with a detailed map-drawing showing all the tavern  buildings and gsounds in de tail. The tavern was her home until she was fourteen years old. A good deal of the information supplied corroborated previous suppositions and some was entirely new. An ex ample of he value of this informa tion is the question of the wooden wing on the west end of the main tavern building j this wing was known to have existed in 1865 it shows up in a wartime photograph, out he trees and shadows obscure details Mrs. Hickok furnishes the first definite knowledge of this wing. It was used as a dining room, and has long since been removed. De tails of the two brick annexes, which were used as guest houses, are also shown, as well as a wooden ser vants quarters behind the main house. The wooden structure stood until recent years, and the three brick structures still stand. Inform ation such as that supplied by Mrs. Hickok will enable the National Park Service to restore the tavern group to its 1865 condition with perfect fidelity. The tavern, according to old re cords, was built in 1819, by Alexan der Patteson and was an important itage stop on the line between Cum berland! County and Lynchburg, wned by Patteson and his brother, Lilburne. In the middle nineteen hundreds the spot was a thriving place, with coaches hearing such ro mantic names as  The Davy Crock ett, her of the Alamo, plying the ,ild stage route. At the time of the formation of Appomattox County, in 1845, the tavern was the property of Captain John Raine. Clover Hill, the name of the place, attached It self to the county seat which was established there in the 1840s, and the town at the time of Lees sur -  render was known both as Appo mattox Court House and Clover Hill the name Clover Hiil still survives as a magesterial distict Such information as hat supplied by Mis. Hickok, adding to previous knowledge and clarifying many point is always very welcome, Sup- rintendent H. A. Gurney points out. He and his stelf ari always in terested in seeing old photographs nd drawings and are gratified at the interest shown by loca people n the work of restoring the scene of the village where a new United States was born when brothers laid down the sword on April !, 1865.

document.text: Today visitors to Appomattox Court House National Historical Park journey back into history as they enter the Meeks Coun try Store in the restored vil- lag e of Appomattox Co u rt House. The store has been re furnished in part to its ap pearance during the 1860s. Many items reminiscent of this period are on sale to visitors by the Eastern National Park  Monument Association. One of its store keepers is Winnie Martin of Appomattox pictured above in her period costume. Mrs. Martin along with Mrs. Marion Godsey and several Vol- unteers-In-Parks from Appo mattox have added a historical- touch to the country store in the last few years by appearing in costume. Visitor reactions are very favorable and their visit to the park is greatly en riched by the presence of these gracious ladies of Appomattox.

document.text: As another April 9. rolls around, Old Appomattox Court House is fast coming to look like the village it was in 1865 when Generals Lee and Grant made peace for America in the home of Wilmer McLean. H. A. Gurney, National Park Serv ice Superintendent at Old Appomat tox, today described progress of the restoration. Restoration of the Peers house should be completed by July 1. The residence was the home of George Peers, county court clerk. New comfort stations, in the re constructed slave quarters at the Old Tavern, will be completed this month and the Tavern itself is being given a handsome reconstruction job. It will be used for National Park Serv ice offices, and will house the enlarg ed museum. New museum exhibits are expect ed to arrive the week of April 18, to add to the many historical relics now on display. The museum has been located in the old Ferguson residence, where there hag not been room for adequate display. A continuous effort goes to ob tain museum items for Appomattox. Many of the items secured during the past year have been sent to Park Service shops to be prepared for ex hibit, and some of these items are now ready for public view. The mu seum in the restored Tavern is ex pected to be a mecca for tourists. Mr. Gurney announced today that 5,800 is now available for buildirg an utility house east of the Peers House. This will furnish storage space, workshop and housing for tools. Work will begin very soon on this project. The program of the Park Serv ice is a restoration of the Old Court Houte Village. The McLean House itself was the top item in the pro gram and-4to dedication brought one of the largest crowds ever in A ddo - mattox. StiH in the making are plans for rebuilding the ojd court house, which was located in the village circle, and was a center of county activity un til it burned in 1892. In Washington this week, final ap proval was voted for a change in the name of the National Park Serv- ice establishment here. The new name will be Appomattox Court House National Historical Park. This replaces the use of the word Monument in the designation, held to be an inadequate descrip tion of the restoration. The bill to change the name was introduced in ttie House by Congressman W. M. Abbitt. It has now passed both the House and Senate. It is of interest to note that the only other National Historical Park in Virginia is Co lonial.

Offers of Help Centennial chairman William Hubbard read a letter from Rev erend O. D. Moore, head of the local ministerial association, which said the Appomattox min isters were sympathetic to the general aims of the Peace Com memoration, and pledging clergy mans help, if needed. Hubbard also read a letter from C. Lewis McDeaimon, Ap pomattox Oil distributor, with an offer to make property available for a tourists center or other Centennial commemoration use. Said Wescoat Wolfe, historian from Appomattox Court House National Historical Park, Appo mattox is just as important ag Gettysburg  perhaps more so. He gave the opinion that there should be a lot of preliminary activities among local groups be fore April 9, 1965. However, he added, Its not fair to the United States to put the commemoration in the hands of Appomattox alone. This is of national Importance. Mrs. Grey Holland advised the group that the Appomattox Gar den Club has been making plans for a beautification project. Lets not depend entirely on the Park Service, she said, and lets not forget to include teen agers in our plans. Centennial Committee Goals Centennial chairman Hubbard set forth the committees tenta tive goals to the supervisors He said. The committee plans to hold a peace commemoration at the old courthouse on the Sunday fol lowing April 9, 1965, with an appropriate historian as one of the guest speakers. The committee also plans to invite the President of the United States, those U. S. Army generals who have signed a peace treaty and ail former presidents. During the summer of 1965, the committee hopes to sponsor the participation by states hav ing battle groups at Appomattox at the 1865 surrender in some type of commemoration service which would rot result in the placing of statues or monuments. document.text: Grover E. Steele has been named Superintendent of Appo mattox Court House National Historical Park Director Conrad L. Wirth of the National Park Service announced today. Steele succeeds Thomas F. Norris, who was recently appointed Superin tendent of Fort Smith National Historic Site in Arkansas. Steele has been Supervisory Park Ranger at Rocky Mountain National Park in Colorado since 1960 During his 16-Vi years with the National Park Service he has also had Ranger assignments at Big Bend National Park in Texas and at Organ Pipe Cactus and Saguaro National Monuments in Arizona. At Appomattox Court House, Virginia, on April 9, 1865, Gener al Robert E. Lee surrendered to General Ulysses S. Grant the most renowned and successful of all Confederate Armies. In April 1940, the Congress author ized establishment of the Natio nal Historical Park to commem- rate the end of the Civil War. The park includes the old village of Appomattox Court House, and Steele will continue the program of restoration and reconstruction of the historic buildings in the village In time for the Centennial observance in April 1965. A native of Texas, Steele serv ed with the U. S. Air Force dur ing World War II. He will be accompanied to Appomattox by his wife, Hazel, and their four children.

The National Park Service has notified park superintend ents that until Congress acts on amendments to the Land and Water Conservation Act, only daily fees will be collected. Pending legislation would pro vide for continuation of public sale of the Golden Eagle annual entrance fee permit. The 1 per car entrance fee at Appomattox Court House Nat ional Historical Park will be collected from April 1 through October 31. Daily entrance fees range from 1 to 3 per car and its occupants at most parks and re  creation areas and user fees from 10? to ride the Washing ton Monument elevator, to 2 -4 for overnight camping in the 86 National Park areas provid ing camping facilities.
